caption: FID vs Training iterations. SCT has faster convergence speed and better performance upper bound than ECT.
description: This chart displays the FID scores plotted against training iterations for both ECT and SCT methods, shown separately for 1-step and 2-step generation.  The log scale on the y-axis highlights the FID score improvement over training time. In both 1-step and 2-step scenarios, SCT demonstrates significantly faster convergence, reaching a lower FID score (indicating better performance) compared to ECT within the same number of training iterations.  Inset graphs provide a zoomed-in view of the final training iterations, further emphasizing the performance gap between SCT and ECT.

caption: Comparison of Methods on 1-step and 2-step FID
description: The chart displays a comparison of FID scores for one-step and two-step generation across three different methods: a baseline without a stable training target, a method using a stable target computed within each training batch, and a method employing a stable target computed from all training samples.  The x-axis represents the method used, while the y-axis shows the FID score for both one-step (left y-axis, teal line) and two-step (right y-axis, green dashed line) generation.  The results clearly indicate that incorporating a stable training target, especially when calculated from all training data, leads to a significant reduction in FID scores for both one-step and two-step generation, demonstrating improved model performance.

caption: Figure 5: The effectiveness of edge-skipping multi-step sampling.
description: The chart displays the FID scores (log scale) on the y-axis against training iterations on the x-axis.  Multiple lines represent different scaling factors (η) used in edge-skipping multistep sampling (η = 0.7, 0.8, 0.9, and 1.0).  The main plot shows the FID scores across the whole training process, while an inset focuses on the final iterations (180k-200k) providing a zoomed-in view of the FID scores at the end of training for each scaling factor. This visualization is used to demonstrate the effects of various edge-skipping factors on the model’s performance.

caption: Figure 6: The effectiveness of classifier-free guidance on consistency models.
description: This chart displays the impact of classifier-free guidance (CFG) strength on the performance of consistency models, measured by FID scores. It presents two sub-charts: one for 1-step FID and another for 2-step FID. Each sub-chart shows FID scores across different CFG strengths (1.00 to 1.40) and different training iterations (25%, 50%, 75%). The x-axis represents the CFG strength, while the y-axis represents the FID score. The lines in each chart represent the FID scores at different iterations, allowing for observation of the impact of CFG strength across the training process.
